intro: Alyssum amasianum, commonly known as the Armenian alyssum, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and Turkey. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other flowering plants with small, four-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters and produces clusters of fragrant, white or pale yellow flowers. Its leaves are alternate, linear, and covered in fine hairs, giving them a slightly fuzzy texture. Alyssum amasianum is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine in some regions.
